**Introduction**
Multi-tenant Snowflake applications typically conform to one of three design patterns:
‚óè
**Multi-Tenant Table (MTT)** : MTT consolidates tenants within a shared table or warehouse.
Centralizing tenants in single, shared objects enables tenants to share compute and other
resources efficiently.
‚óè
**Object Per Tenant (OPT):** OPT isolates tenants into separate tables, schemas, databases,
and warehouses. Although this approach allocates individual objects to tenants, the
application still operates within a single Snowflake account.
‚óè
**Account Per Tenant (APT):** APT isolates tenants into separate Snowflake accounts. Unlike
OPT, each tenant within the application has its own dedicated Snowflake account.
Tenancy models have different advantages regarding security, storage, compute, and connectivity,
and a hybrid approach may be needed to properly address these considerations. Hybrids between
tenancy models are common. For example, a design might use a multi-tenant table to consolidate
storage but allocate dedicated compute resources to each tenant, thereby forming an MTT/OPT
hybrid design.
This white paper has three parts:
‚óè
Part One helps data application builders understand the pros-and-cons and
costs-and-benefits of the various patterns
‚óè
Part Two describes each pattern in greater detail and offers guidance on the Snowflake
features required for proper implementation
‚óè
Part Three provides additional information to help you evaluate tenancy models based on
security, storage, and compute requirements
**Part One: Comparing Multi-Tenant**
**Design Patterns**
This section compares and contrasts the three patterns and describes the requirements that tend
to favor one design approach over the others.
Multi-tenant table (MTT)
MTT's chief characteristics are **scalability** and **architectural simplicity** .
‚óè
MTT is the most scalable design pattern in terms of the number of tenants an application
can support. This approach supports apps with millions of tenants.
Page 2
‚óè
It has a simpler architecture within Snowflake. Simplicity matters because object
proliferation makes managing myriad objects increasingly difficult over time. With MTT,
adding tenants does not cause the number of objects to grow, but adding tenants to OPT
and APT can result in hundreds or thousands of objects being created within Snowflake.
From a cost standpoint, MTT is usually more cost-efficient because multiple customers utilize
shared compute and other resources more efficiently.
But MTT has a somewhat rigid requirement: To use MTT, an app's data model has to have the same
general shape across all tenants. Application builders can achieve slight variances using custom
 ... 
dedicated warehouses based on application requirements
‚óè
Use different warehouses for different application purposes
‚óè
Isolate other workloads to their own warehouses
When it comes to tenants, app builders need to make decisions around whether to give tenants a
dedicated warehouse, versus pooling them on common warehouses or multi-cluster warehouses.
Cost will be a factor. You can pool dashboard queries more easily than ad hoc queries because
they're predictable. Ad hoc usage can introduce unexpected and unplanned expenses. Strict COGS
per tenant calculations are a reason to separate tenants into dedicated warehouses because
pooled heuristics are less precise. Some applications pool users by default but offer the option to
pay extra to get a dedicated warehouse.

Section Title: üßä Single vs. Multi-Tenancy in Snowflake: A Practical Breakdown for Data Architects > Contents
Content:
‚àò üîç What Does ‚ÄúTenancy‚Äù Mean in Snowflake?
‚àò üß± Single-Tenant Vs Multi-Tenant Comparison
‚àò üîê Security & Compliance Considerations
‚àò ‚öôÔ∏è Performance & Cost: What to Expect
‚àò üíµ Billing Implications
‚àò üß≠ Decision Guide: Which One Should You Choose?
‚àò üßæ Final Thoughts
*‚ÄúShould I go single-tenant or multi-tenant in Snowflake?‚Äù* If you‚Äôve asked this question before ‚Äî or had a strong opinion on it ‚Äî this article is for you.
Snowflake‚Äôs flexible architecture is one of the platform‚Äôs biggest strengths, but with great flexibility comes decision fatigue. One key design choice that data teams often grapple with early on is whether to go with a **single-tenant** or **multi-tenant** account strategy.
This article unpacks both approaches in the context of Snowflake, their trade-offs, use cases, and what you should consider when making your choice.
Section Title: ... > üîç What Does ‚ÄúTenancy‚Äù Mean in Snowflake?
Content:
Let‚Äôs start with a quick refresher:
Section Title: ... > üîç What Does ‚ÄúTenancy‚Äù Mean in Snowflake?
Content:
**Single-tenancy** : In this model, each individual customer, specific business unit, or unique use case is allocated its own dedicated and **isolated Snowflake account** . This approach ensures that the data and resources of one customer remain completely separate from those of others, providing enhanced security and tailored performance for each user‚Äôs needs. By utilizing single-tenancy, organizations can have greater control over their data environment, facilitating customized configurations and optimizations that align with their specific operational requirements. **Multi-tenancy** refers to a robust architectural approach where multiple tenants, or users, can share a **single Snowflake account** . This design not only enhances resource efficiency but also provides a seamless experience for users. Within this framework, there is a logical separation of data and access through the use of roles, databases, and schemas.
Section Title: ... > üîç What Does ‚ÄúTenancy‚Äù Mean in Snowflake?
Content:
Each tenant can operate independently while still benefiting from the shared infrastructure, ensuring that their data remains secure and isolated from others. This model is particularly advantageous for organizations looking to optimize their resources while maintaining strict data governance and security protocols.
 ... 
Section Title: ... > ‚öôÔ∏è Performance & Cost: What to Expect
Content:
The architecture is designed to provide each account with its own dedicated virtual warehouses. This means that resources are allocated specifically for each individual account, ensuring that performance is optimized and tailored to the needs of that particular tenant. One of the significant advantages of this model is the elimination of the risk associated with ‚Äúnoisy neighbors,‚Äù which refers to the potential performance degradation that can occur when multiple tenants share the same resources. In a single-tenant environment, each account operates independently, thus avoiding any interference from other tenants‚Äô activities. It is important to consider some potential downsides of this model. For instance, if the tenants utilizing the system are small or if their usage patterns are uneven, there is a possibility that you might end up paying for idle compute resources.
 ... 
Section Title: ... > üßæ Final Thoughts
Content:
Choosing between **single-tenancy** and **multi-tenancy** in Snowflake isn‚Äôt just a technical decision ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic one that touches architecture, governance, security, cost, and user experience. There‚Äôs no universal right answer, and often, the best solution lies in **hybrid models** that evolve with your platform‚Äôs maturity and customer needs.
The key is understanding your **business context** , **compliance requirements** , and **operational capabilities** ‚Äî then designing for clarity, control, and scale.
Whether you‚Äôre architecting a multi-tenant SaaS platform or segmenting business units within an enterprise, Snowflake gives you the flexibility to do both ‚Äî **just make sure you have the governance to match the power** .
Thanks for reading! If this sparked ideas or questions ‚Äî or if you have your own patterns and lessons to share ‚Äî I‚Äôd love to connect. The data community only gets better when we learn from each other.

Section Title: ... > After some consultation and discovery, it was clear we needed to focus on:
Content:
While this is an abbreviated list of requirements, these are an example of some of the aspects one needs to consider when designing a multi-tenant architecture for your data platform. As you may have guessed, it‚Äôs no surprise that the client saw Snowflake Cloud Data Warehouse as a major enabler of this kind of architecture.
Snowflake has a rich ecosystem of 3rd party data integration technologies and native features such as Snowpipe to integrate data. Additionally, if the data cannot be brought in for compliance reasons, Snowflake can integrate with external data lakes.
Snowflake governance and security model is based on both Role Based Access Control and Discretionary Access control principles. It allows for a flexible governance framework within Snowflake accounts. However, you can scale your Access Control model across multiple snowflake accounts in a federated model.
Section Title: ... > After some consultation and discovery, it was clear we needed to focus on:
Content:
Snowflake native separation of storage and compute and cost control mechanisms allow dedicated computing for workloads and the ability to track those compute and storage costs granularly.
Snowflake data-sharing features allow different accounts to securely share data without physically moving the data. This will enable data to stay federated yet accessible for querying with proper governance and security controls.
Understanding your technical, business, and compliance requirements is key to designing a successful multi-tenant architecture. Luckily, Snowflake has many features necessary to develop it securely, efficiently, and cost-effectively.
Let‚Äôs look at Snowflake‚Äôs recommended architectural patterns, best practices, and suggestions for designing your own Snowflake Multi-Tenant data warehouse solution.

Section Title: ... > Pros
Content:
OPT is an ideal solution when each tenant has a unique data model.
Some customers prefer the OPT model to avoid managing entitlement tables, secure views, or row-level security requiring solid processes.
The OPT design pattern considers security as a critical factor. Some apps utilizing the OPT model provide customers with dedicated computing resources to meet contractual, security, or regulatory requirements.
 ... 
Section Title: ... > Best practices
Content:
It is common practice to separate customers into their databases as it provides the most straightforward and cleanest isolation level. However, some app builders choose to separate customers into dedicated tables, for instance, in embedded analytics use cases where data applications create a report table per tenant.
Implement OPT authentication and authorization similar to MTT. However, it is advisable to implement a user lookup process within the secrets manager and application tier to route the user to the proper database automatically and the correct warehouse.
Tenant data can be ingested and transformed through a single working database and then distributed to tenant-serving databases to optimize efficiency and cost-effectiveness. However, Keeping the same tenant-per-database separation at this level is also possible.

Section Title: ... > Overview of Snowflake Native App security requirements ¬∂
Content:
The Snowflake Native App Framework provides security requirements and best practices that providers must follow when
developing a Snowflake Native App. For security requirements and best practices for an app, see Security requirements and best practices for a Snowflake Native App . For security requirements for an app with containers, see Secure a Snowflake Native App with Snowpark Container Services .
To publish an app to consumers, either as a private listing or on Snowflake Marketplace,
Snowflake implements a security review process that requires a security scan of the components
of an app. If an app does not pass the automated security review, a manual review occurs.
All apps that are published to consumers must pass this security review.
Section Title: Security requirements and guidelines for a Snowflake Native App ¬∂ > Potential security risks ¬∂
Content:
The following are some of the possible security risks that can occur when running an app:
Data exfiltration:Malicious apps could copy consumer data to external functions or logs.
Compute abuse:Apps could perform unauthorized tasks, such as cryptomining, at the consumer‚Äôs expense.
RansomwareApps could encrypt or corrupt consumer data, demanding payment for restoration.
Privilege escalation:Apps could attempt to gain unauthorized permissions within the consumer‚Äôs account.
To mitigate these and other possible security risks, the Snowflake Native App Framework uses a security review to evaluate
an app for security risks and to ensure security best practices.
Section Title: Security requirements and guidelines for a Snowflake Native App ¬∂ > Automated security reviews ¬∂
Content:
To mitigate potential security risks, Snowflake uses the Native App Anti-Abuse Pipeline Service (NAAAPS).
This service automatically scans all new app versions using various tools to determine if an app can
be distributed to consumers.
This automated security review occurs when a new version or patch of an app is created. This review
performs the following:
Copies the app to a dedicated Snowflake account used to scan apps.
Scans the files associated with the app and updates the security review status.
Auto-approves the app or initiates a manual review of the app.
During the manual review process, an app can be approved or rejected. Snowflake does not send a notification if an
app is rejected. Providers can view the status of the review in
Snowsight.
Section Title: ... > Scanners and tools used during a security review ¬∂
Content:
The automated security review uses the following scanners and tools to perform the
following to analyze different components of an app:
Scan code for bugs, anti-patterns, and security vulnerabilities in code.
Scan code for malware.
Identify vulnerabilities in app dependencies.
The processes help detect various security issues, such as data exfiltration, ransomware, compute
abuse, privilege escalation, and dynamic code execution.
Section Title: ... > Security requirements and best practices for an app ¬∂
Content:
All apps must conform to the security requirements outlined in the Security requirements and best practices for a Snowflake Native App .
Note
Security requirements are subject to change as Snowflake continues to monitor new potential risks.

This topic describes the security requirements and best practices that providers must

outlined in the following sections:
Security requirements for application code
Security requirements for app functionality
Security requirements for app permissions
Note
Security requirements are subject to change as Snowflake continues to monitor new potential risks.
Section Title: ... > Security requirements for application code ¬∂
Content:
App code included within an application package must conform to the following security requirements:
Your app must not load or execute any code from outside the application package except
Snowflake-provided libraries. All the app code, including all library dependencies and setup code,
must be included in the app version defined in the application package.
All app code must be un-obfuscated, meaning that the code must be human readable. This requirement
includes minified JavaScript code.NoteIf an app needs to use minified JavaScript code, it must include a corresponding source map file
that can be used to recover the un-minified code.
All dependencies or libraries with critical or high common vulnerabilities and exposures (CVE) must be
updated to a secure version, if available.
 ... 
Section Title: ... > Security requirements for app functionality ¬∂
Content:
Harm includes but is not limited to:
Data leakage and/or loss;
Restricting consumer access to their data unless explicitly designed as part of the app
functionality, for example, data masking for data access policies. Excessive resource consumption. Arbitrary code injection/execution. All connections to an app, including web-based user interfaces and APIs, must first authenticate using a
Snowflake-provided method of authentication. Any app-specific authentication must be presented to users
after Snowflake authentication has succeeded. Apps should not create any public endpoints that allow connections to the app without a successful
authentication through Snowflake first.
 ... 
Section Title: ... > Recommended security best practices for an app with containers ¬∂
Content:
Limit the use of external dependencies and libraries to minimize the attack surface of an app and
reduce the risk of supply chain vulnerabilities. Follow container image hardening requirements, such as the use of minimal base images, removal of
unnecessary packages, and secure configuration of runtime environments. Use secure communication protocols and encryption for all inter-container and external communication. Generate comprehensive logging and auditing of container activities and data access patterns. Update and patch container images regularly to address known vulnerabilities and security issues. Implement only required privileges to minimizing the attack surface of containerized apps. Managing secrets and sensitive data securely, using appropriate encryption and access controls. Conduct thorough security testing and vulnerability assessments before submitting apps for review.
Section Title: ... > Recommended security best practices for an app with containers ¬∂
Content:
Respond promptly to security incidents and collaborate with Snowflake during incident response. Provide clear and accurate documentation of app functionality, dependencies, and security controls. Educate and guide consumers on the secure use and configuration of their apps.
 ... 
Section Title: ... > Best practices for developing and publishing an application package ¬∂
Content:
By following the best practice of having separate development and production packages, developers can maintain an efficient
development lifecycle while ensuring that only secure and approved versions of the app are published and
distributed to external consumers.

Section Title: Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake
Content:
Multi-tenant design patterns fit for purpose on Snowflake AI Data Cloud
Section Title: ... > Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake: Choosing the Right Model
Content:
Snowflake‚Äôs flexibility makes it a powerful foundation for multi-tenant data platforms‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre an internal team supporting multiple business verticals, a consulting firm recommending architecture for a client, or a SaaS producer embedding Snowflake into your product. However, that flexibility comes with a key architectural choice: **how do you isolate tenants?**
Snowflake offers three broad design patterns:
**Account per Tenant** (single Snowflake account per tenant)
**Object per Tenant** (schemas, databases, warehouses inside a shared account)
**Multi-Tenant Tables** (shared tables with row-level separation)
Each model has trade-offs in **management complexity, cost, and security** , and the right choice often depends on how you run pipelines, deploy dbt or transformation projects, manage cloud integrations, and enforce governance.
Section Title: Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake > ... > The Models in Detail > 1. Account per Tenant
Content:
**Strongest isolation** but also the most expensive and operationally heavy.
Each account can have its own Snowflake account, dbt repo, CI/CD pipeline, and cloud integrations.
Best suited for regulated industries, high-sensitivity clients, or consulting engagements where clear boundaries are required.
 ... 
Section Title: Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake > ... > Beyond the Models: Collaboration & Operational Fit
Content:
Choosing a pattern isn‚Äôt just about cost or security‚Äîit‚Äôs also about **how people collaborate** on data infrastructure.
For example:
In an **Object per Tenant** model, you may want to provide external access to a dbt or a Terraform repository. Sharing one central repo often isn‚Äôt practical, so you end up spinning up **multiple repos** to isolate access. That increases repo sprawl and CI/CD complexity.
In an **Account per Tenant** model, repo isolation comes naturally, but now you‚Äôre duplicating a lot of infrastructure.
In a **Multi-Tenant Table** model, collaboration is centralized, but you can‚Äôt easily let tenants contribute directly without exposing all logic.
‚Äç
The lesson: **Your multi-tenant strategy is also a collaboration strategy.** Decisions about Snowflake isolation ripple into repo structures, CI/CD design, and who owns which part of the stack.
Section Title: Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake > ... > Hybrid Approaches: The Real-World Default
Content:
In practice, most organizations don‚Äôt pick just one pattern‚Äîthey blend them. Examples:
**Object per Tenant for Snowflake objects** , but **individual dbt repos per org** so each vertical or client can control transformations independently.
**Object per Tenant for storage** (separate schemas/databases), but **Multi-Tenant Tables for compute** so warehouses can be pooled to minimize cost.
**Multi-Tenant Tables for staging raw data** , but **Account per Tenant for production workloads** when clients require strong SLAs and security (example leveraging a Snowflake Data Share for sharing data).
‚Äç
These hybrid solutions recognize that **no single model is perfect** . Teams often optimize isolation at one layer (security, repos, or cloud integration) while pooling resources at another (compute, storage, orchestration).
Section Title: Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake > ... > Collaboration Questions to Ask
Content:
When designing your architecture, don‚Äôt just ask ‚ÄúWhich pattern fits?‚Äù Ask:
Do tenants need repo access (dbt, Terraform etc.) and at what level?
How much repo isolation can we handle operationally?
Who owns Snowflake infrastructure vs transformation logic?
How will we enforce network policies and cloud storage integrations (AWS, Azure, GCP)?
Where do we want to optimize for cost vs security vs maintainability?
Section Title: Multi-Tenant Design Patterns on Snowflake > ... > The Models in Detail > Choosing the Right Approach
Content:
**Account per Tenant** ‚Üí when compliance, strict security, or large enterprise clients demand isolation.
**Object per Tenant** ‚Üí when you want balance: good isolation, manageable repos, and pooled cloud integration.
**Multi-Tenant Tables** ‚Üí when you‚Äôre optimizing for SaaS scale and cost.
**Hybrid models** ‚Üí when you need to blend isolation and efficiency, e.g., object-level separation for governance + shared compute for cost savings.
‚Äç
The decision isn‚Äôt just **architecture** . It‚Äôs **architecture + collaboration + governance** . Get all three right, and your Snowflake multi-tenant design will scale with your business.
Need help in planning or optimizing your setup? We're here to help. [**Contact us**](https://www.leolytixco.com/contact) to learn more.
‚Äç
